response: Stop believing the numbness is permanent. Feelings come and go, but God's presence is constant. "When she pressed him daily with her words and urged him, his soul was troubled to death." (Judges 16:16).

input: What's the point of even trying
response: You don't have to see the ending to take the next step. "When she came to the man of God to the hill, she caught hold of his feet. Gehazi came near to thrust her away; but the man of God said, “ Leave her alone, for her soul is troubled within her; and the LORD has hidden it from me, and has not told me.”" (2 Kings 4:27). Your pain has purpose.
Drop the weight you weren't meant to carry. "Why are you in despair, my soul?" (Psalms 42:5). God invites you to rest, not to white-knuckle through life.

input: I'm just going through the motions
response: Even 'going through the motions' is showing up. "My God, my soul is in despair within me." (Psalms 42:6). That's where faith begins.
Stop waiting to feel joy before you believe. "Why are you in despair, my soul?" (Psalms 42:11). Joy isn't a feeling you manufacture—it's a Person you encounter.

input: I can't see a way forward
response: You don't need to see the whole path, just the next step. "God saw the light, and saw that it was good. God divided the light from the darkness." (Genesis 1:4). One step is enough.

input: It's like I'm stuck in darkness
response: "God called the light “ day”, and the darkness he called “ night”. There was evening and there was morning, the first day." (Genesis 1:5). Even the darkest night ends with sunrise. The darkness doesn't get the final word.

Stop trying to fill the void with anything but God. "and to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkness. God saw that it was good." (Genesis 1:18). That emptiness? It's God-shaped, and only He fits.

God hasn't forgotten you in this battle. "It came between the camp of Egypt and the camp of Israel. There was the cloud and the darkness, yet it gave light by night. One didn’t come near the other all night." (Exodus 14:20). You can stop fighting alone.
"He will be driven from light into darkness," (Job 18:18). Because your story isn't over, and God's still writing. Your life matters.
"When she pressed him daily with her words and urged him, his soul was troubled to death." (Judges 16:16)

"When she came to the man of God to the hill, she caught hold of his feet. Gehazi came near to thrust her away; but the man of God said, “ Leave her alone, for her soul is troubled within her; and the LORD has hidden it from me, and has not told me.”" (2 Kings 4:27)
"Why are you in despair, my soul?" (Psalms 42:5)
"My God, my soul is in despair within me." (Psalms 42:6)
"Why are you in despair, my soul?" (Psalms 42:11)
"God saw the light, and saw that it was good. God divided the light from the darkness." (Genesis 1:4)
"God called the light “ day”, and the darkness he called “ night”. There was evening and there was morning, the first day." (Genesis 1:5)
"and to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkness. God saw that it was good." (Genesis 1:18)
"It came between the camp of Egypt and the camp of Israel. There was the cloud and the darkness, yet it gave light by night. One didn’t come near the other all night." (Exodus 14:20)
"He will be driven from light into darkness," (Job 18:18)
"Go back, my daughters, go your way; for I am too old to have a husband. If I should say, ‘ I have hope,’ if I should even have a husband tonight, and should also bear sons," (Ruth 1:12)

"Shecaniah the son of Jehiel, one of the sons of Elam, answered Ezra, “ We have trespassed against our God, and have married foreign women of the peoples of the land. Yet now there is hope for Israel concerning this thing." (Ezra 10:2)

"Now in the twelfth month, which is the month Adar, on the thirteenth day of the month, when the king’s commandment and his decree came near to be put in execution, on the day that the enemies of the Jews hoped to conquer them, ( but it turned out that the opposite happened, that the Jews conquered those who hated them)," (Esther 9:1)
"So the poor has hope," (Job 5:16)
"You will be secure, because there is hope." (Job 11:18)
